column4: Dollar General to hire up to 20,000 workers as economy rebounds
column5: Dollar General Corp (DG.N) said on Wednesday it would recruit up to 20,000 employees this spring, the latest company to plan a hiring spree as more parts of the U.S. economy reopen and fiscal stimulus kicks in.
column6: But the number was lower than the more than 50,000 workers the company hired around the same time last year, which was nearly double its normal hiring rate, to support a surge in sales at its stores at the height of COVID-19 lockdowns.
column7: The discount retailer said in a statement on Wednesday that it would host hiring events from this month to fill positions in its stores, distribution centers and corporate offices.
column8: Strengthening domestic demand, the rollout of COVID-19 vaccines and additional pandemic aid from the government have boosted companies' needs for workers, with McDonald's Corp (MCD.N) and Yum Brands' (YUM.N) Taco Bell saying recently that they were looking to hire thousands of workers. read more

column4: Dollar General warns of dropping sales, uncertain of stimulus impact
column5: (Reuters) - Dollar General indicated on Thursday the vaccine rollout and a reopening economy would lead to a bigger-than-expected slowdown in sales for discounted groceries, while a new round of stimulus may be tougher to take advantage of than before.
column6: The company’s shares fell over 6% as it also forecast full-year profit below estimates.
column7: The promise of a return to relative normalcy later this year as more Americans get inoculated against COVID-19 has made the boom in pantry stocking, which made Dollar General one of the bigger retail beneficiaries of the health crisis, unlikely to be repeated.
column8: A new round of $1,400 stimulus payments, on the way to mostly lower- and middle-income households, was expected to boost spending at discount stores, at least in the coming weeks, but Dollar General said there was too much uncertainty about how much the company could benefit to include it in its outlook.
column9: “Compared to the previous stimulus rounds, which helped us, the economy is now opening up more. We are competing with other segments of the economy outside of retail for that share of wallet, so how much we get is uncertain,” finance chief John Garratt said on a call with analysts.
column10: Dollar General said it expects full-year same-store sales to fall 4% to 6%, compared with estimates of a 1.2% decline, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. The company forecast overall net sales to be flat to 2% lower, compared with estimates of a 1.4% increase.
column11: The company forecast annual earnings per share of $8.80 to $9.50, below estimates of $10.08.
column12: Same-store sales in the fourth quarter rose 12.7%, beating analysts’ estimate of a 10.7% increase, helped by the $600 stimulus checks that boosted spending.
column13: Net income rose about 20% to $642.7 million, or $2.62 per share, but missed estimates of $2.72 per share.

column4: Dollar General forecasts full-year same-store sales below estimates
column5: Dollar General (DG.N) indicated on Thursday the vaccine rollout and a reopening economy would lead to a bigger-than-expected slowdown in sales for discounted groceries, while a new round of stimulus may be tougher to take advantage of than before.
column6: The company's shares fell over 6% as it also forecast full-year profit below estimates.
column7: The promise of a return to relative normalcy later this year as more Americans get inoculated against COVID-19 has made the boom in pantry stocking, which made Dollar General one of the bigger retail beneficiaries of the health crisis, unlikely to be repeated.
column8: A new round of $1,400 stimulus payments, on the way to mostly lower- and middle-income households, was expected to boost spending at discount stores, at least in the coming weeks, but Dollar General said there was too much uncertainty about how much the company could benefit to include it in its outlook.
column9: "Compared to the previous stimulus rounds, which helped us, the economy is now opening up more. We are competing with other segments of the economy outside of retail for that share of wallet, so how much we get is uncertain," finance chief John Garratt said on a call with analysts.
column10: Dollar General said it expects full-year same-store sales to fall 4% to 6%, compared with estimates of a 1.2% decline, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. The company forecast overall net sales to be flat to 2% lower, compared with estimates of a 1.4% increase.
column11: The company forecast annual earnings per share of $8.80 to $9.50, below estimates of $10.08.
column12: Same-store sales in the fourth quarter rose 12.7%, beating analysts' estimate of a 10.7% increase, helped by the $600 stimulus checks that boosted spending.
column13: Net income rose about 20% to $642.7 million, or $2.62 per share, but missed estimates of $2.72 per share.

column4: Exclusive: Discount retailer Dollar General takes steps to find possible CEO successor - sources
column5: (Reuters) - Discount chain Dollar General Corp, one of the few U.S. retailers thriving during the COVID-19 pandemic, is taking steps to find a potential successor to Chief Executive Todd Vasos, people familiar with the matter said on Monday.
column6: While no decision has been made about Vasos stepping down, Dollar General has started conversations with headhunting firms and is considering candidates, the sources said.
column7: Dollar General has been looking within its ranks and will assess the performance of its top executives against those at rival companies, the sources said. Dollar General Chief Operating Officer Jeff Owen is under consideration, one of the sources added.
column8: The sources requested anonymity because the matter is confidential.
column9: A Dollar General spokesman said Vasos had not communicated any plans to the company regarding a potential departure after his contract ends in June, noting it was “merely good governance” to plan for a transition. Vasos’ contract renews automatically on an annual basis in June unless terminated or renegotiated.
column10: “We have been speaking with management consulting firms related to executive development programs and as part of our succession planning process. We have not entered into a contract with any such firm to date,” the spokesman said.
column11: Vasos has expanded Dollar General’s offerings to include more fresh produce and is wooing higher-income shoppers with new products in categories such as home decor, in a bid to stave off competition from large rivals such as Walmart Inc and Amazon.com Inc.
column12: Dollar General has also invested heavily in private label brands, developing lines for items ranging from cat food to shampoo. It has added more distribution centers to supply its stores with dairy products, deli meats and frozen entrees. It has more than 16,000 stores, often in areas underserved by other retailers.
column13: Dollar General shares have risen 170% since Vasos became CEO in 2015, compared to a 115% rise in the S&P 500 General Merchandise Stores index over the same period.
column14: The COVID-19 outbreak has boosted Dollar General’s sales, as shoppers stay home more and buy more household necessities. Dollar General operates in small communities with few retailers.
column15: The Goodlettsville, Tennessee-based company has taken steps to protect its more than 157,000 workers during the pandemic, and announced last month that it would pay its hourly and salaried workers for receiving COVID-19 vaccines.
column16: It also said it would award $50 million in appreciation bonuses to its frontline workers in its fourth quarter, for a total of up to about $173 million for fiscal 2020.

column4: Lidl offers $200 extra to U.S. workers to get COVID-19 vaccination
column5: (Reuters) - German discount supermarket chain Lidl said on Wednesday it is providing an extra $200 to all its U.S. employees who get vaccinated for COVID-19, as states make shots more widely available.
column6: The announcement follows similar moves from peers Aldi and Dollar General Corp, as well as grocery delivery firm Instacart, with Lidl’s incentive among the biggest a company has offered its U.S. workers so far.
column7: Lidl said its employees were “eager” to get vaccinated, citing an internal survey in which nearly eight in 10 workers said they planned to get inoculated as soon as a vaccine became available.
column8: The company sells its products in more than 125 stores across nine East Coast U.S. states.

column4: Supermarket chain Aldi to pay U.S. workers who get COVID-19 vaccination
column5: German supermarket chain Aldi (ALDIEI.UL) on Tuesday became the latest firm in the grocery sector to offer incentives for U.S. employees getting a COVID-19 vaccine, saying it would give up to four hours of pay to those who choose to receive inoculations.
column6: The retailer, which has more than 2,000 stores in 37 U.S. states, said it would cover costs associated with vaccine administration and implement on-site vaccination clinics at its warehouse and office locations.
column7: Dollar General Corp (DG.N) last week offered frontline employees a similar incentive after they get the vaccine, while grocery delivery company Instacart said it would pay $25 to more than half-a-million gig workers if they chose to take time off to get vaccinated. read more
column8: Aldi said it was working with officials across the United States to get workers priority access to the vaccine, joining other companies including Amazon.com Inc (AMZN.O) and Uber Technologies Inc (UBER.N) lobbying to move workers closer to the front of the line for vaccinations.
column9: However, conflicting state and local guidelines on how shots will be administered and to which workers have made the process of navigating the vaccine rollout confusing for corporations and industry bodies. read more
column10: Most corporations globally have so far been quiet on whether they would try securing doses for employees, even as some Indian firms are considering buying COVID-19 shots outright for their employees, once the vaccines become available commercially. read more

column4: Dollar General plans to pay employees to get COVID-19 vaccination
column5: (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp will offer frontline employees four hours worth of pay after they get the COVID-19 vaccine, the discount retailer said on Wednesday, making it one of first U.S. companies to incentivize its workers to get inoculated.
column6: The retailer, which has about 140,000 employees, said that it was providing hourly employees the one-time benefit to compensate for the time away from the store, while they received the vaccine. (bit.ly/3nGHYSm)
column7: The company added that it was working with distribution and transportation teams to make similar accommodations and said it was providing salaried employees additional store labor hours.
column8: The discount store chain did not mandate all employees to get the vaccine, but encouraged them to do so.
column9: According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, people over 75 and essential workers are scheduled to receive the vaccine in a later phase, after healthcare workers and nursing home residents.
column10: Dollar General was deemed an essential service during the lockdowns, and became one of the few retailers to remain open for people to buy groceries and other daily supplies.
column11: U.S. companies so far have been shying away from discussing vaccine mandates.

column4: Dollar stores thrive in pandemic, but hold back forecasts
column5: (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp reported better-than-expected quarterly results on Thursday, as the discount retailer benefited from higher demand for cheaper groceries and household items during the coronavirus-induced economic downturn.
column6: High unemployment and falling household income this year due to the COVID-19 crisis have boosted demand for lower-priced cereals, vegetables and other essentials, lifting sales at dollar stores.
column7: The strong demand also carried through to the current quarter, with Dollar General reporting same-store sales growth of about 14% for the period between Oct. 31 and Dec.1.
column8: Still, the company did not provide a forecast for the rest of the year, like its peer Dollar Tree, citing the uncertainty caused by the pandemic.
column9: Shares of Dollar General, which typically sells products for $10 or less, were down nearly 3% in premarket trading after having risen about 40% so far this year.
column10: Dollar General has stores concentrated in rural locations, which makes them a one-stop place for customers - who have few other options nearby - to buy everything from home decor, party supplies to everyday essentials.
column11: For the third quarter ended Oct. 30, Dollar General posted sales and same-store sales that beat analysts’ expectations as people bought more on average despite cutting down on the number of trips.
column12: Net income rose to $574.26 million, or $2.31 per share, from $365.55 million, or $1.42 per share, a year earlier.
column13: Analysts on average were expecting a profit of $2.00 per share, Refinitiv IBES data showed.

column4: Dollar General beats quarterly sales estimates
column5: Dec 3 (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp reported better-than-expected quarterly sales on Thursday, as the discount retailer benefited from higher demand for cheaper groceries and household items during the coronavirus-induced economic downturn.
column6: Net sales rose to $8.20 billion in the third quarter ended Oct. 30, narrowly beating the analysts’ average expectation of $8.15 billion, according to Refinitiv IBES data. (Reporting by Mehr Bedi in Bengaluru; Editing by Arun Koyyur)

column4: U.S. dollar chains report profit surge as downturn makes shoppers thrifty
column5: (Reuters) - America’s biggest dollar store chains reported better-than-expected quarterly profit on Thursday, as cash-strapped consumers sought lower priced groceries and household items in a coronavirus-induced economic downturn.
column6: Sales at Dollar General Corp DG.N and Dollar Tree Inc DLTR.O remained robust even after the panic-buying surge at the start of lockdowns, with high U.S. unemployment pushing demand for cheaper cereals, vegetables and daily essentials.
column7: The two dollar stores said sales of more discretionary items including clothing were also up, as households spent government stimulus checks carefully.
column8: But with talks over the new COVID-19 stimulus package stuck in a stalemate, Dollar General warned that comparable sales could moderate from the current 15% growth levels in the coming months.
column9: Smaller rival Dollar Tree remained optimistic for the year, but did not provide a sales outlook.
column10: “We’re going to be in a good position in the back half of the year and going into next year when customers are going to need us most as the extra benefits go away and with the unemployment rate where it is,” Dollar Tree’s new Chief Executive Officer Mike Witynski said.
column11: While shoppers are spending more at dollar stores, they are making fewer trips, which according to Evercore ISI analysts is an opportunity for Walmart Inc WMT.N and Amazon.com Inc AMZN.O to pull away customers with their better developed e-commerce operations.
column12: Interactive graphic on sales comparison here
column13: Dollar General’s second-quarter same-store sales rose 18.8% and beat estimates of a 15.1% increase, but that of Dollar Tree was not as strong, rising 7.2% and sending its shares down 5%.
column14: Net income at Dollar General rose 84.6% to $787.6 million, or $3.12 per share, beating expectations of $2.44. The company said it had begun share buybacks and would repurchase an additional $2 billion worth of stock.
column15: Dollar Tree, which owns the Family Dollar chain, said net income rose 45% to $261.5 million, or $1.10 per share, beating analysts’ estimate of 92 cents.

column4: Dollar General beats quarterly same-store sales estimates
column5: Aug 27 (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp beat quarterly same-store sales estimates on Thursday, as more Americans bought low-price groceries and household items from the discount retailer amid the economic downturn due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
column6: The company, which is raising its share buyback program by $2 billion, said same-store sales rose 18.8% in the second quarter ended July 31, above analysts’ average estimate of a 15.1% increase, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column7: Net income rose to $787.6 million, or $3.12 per share, from $426.6 million, or $1.65 per share, a year earlier. (Reporting by Uday Sampath in Bengaluru; Editing by Arun Koyyur)

column4: BRIEF-Dollar General Corporation Reports First Quarter 2020 Results
column5: May 28 (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp:
column6: * Q1 EARNINGS PER SHARE ESTIMATE $1.74 -- REFINITIV IBES DATA
column7: * Q1 SALES $8.4 BILLION VERSUS REFINITIV IBES ESTIMATE OF $7.61 BILLION
column8: * REALIZED SIGNIFICANT SALES BENEFIT IN Q1 OF FISCAL YEAR AS A RESULT OF COVID-19
column9: * AS OF MAY 1, 2020, TOTAL MERCHANDISE INVENTORIES, AT COST, WERE $4.1 BILLION VERSUS $4.1 BILLION AS OF MAY 3, 2019
column10: * SINCE END OF Q1, CONTINUED TO EXPERIENCE ELEVATED DEMAND IN ITS STORES
column11: * DOLLAR GENERAL - THROUGH MAY 26, 2020, SAME-STORE SALES HAVE INCREASED ABOUT 22% COMPARED TO COMPARABLE PERIOD IN 2019 FISCAL YEAR

column4: Dollar Tree quarterly same-store sales rise 7%
column5: (Reuters) - Dollar Tree Inc DLTR.O reported a surge in quarterly same-store sales on Thursday, joining rival Dollar General DG.N, as the discount retailer benefited from consumers stockpiling on groceries and other essentials due to the coronavirus crisis.
column6: Same-store sales rose 7% in the first quarter ended May 2.
column7: The company withdrew its full-year forecast due to the uncertainty caused by the coronavirus pandemic.
column8: Net income fell to $247.6 million, or $1.04 per share, from $267.9 million, or $1.12 per share, a year earlier.

column4: Dollar General expects to exceed 2020 forecasts after surge in quarterly sales
column5: May 28 (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp said on Thursday it expects to exceed its annual sales and profit forecasts after the retailer saw a surge in demand from customers stocking up on groceries and household essentials amid the COVID-19 pandemic.
column6: The company’s net sales rose to $8.45 billion from $6.62 billion in the first quarter ended May 1. Same-store sales jumped 21.7%.
column7: Dollar General had previously forecast fiscal 2020 net sales to rise 7.5% to 8%. (Reporting by Uday Sampath in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

column4: BRIEF-Dollar General Corp Files For Potential Mixed Shelf Offering
column5: April 1 (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp:
column6: * DOLLAR GENERAL CORP FILES FOR POTENTIAL MIXED SHELF OFFERING; SIZE NOT DISLCLOSED - SEC FILING Source : (bit.ly/2JrFAxb) Further company coverage:

column4: BRIEF-Dollar General Corp Says CEO Todd Vasos' FY 2019 Total Compensation $12.0 Mln Vs $10.6 Mln In FY 2018
column5: March 18 (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp:
column6: * DOLLAR GENERAL CORP SAYS CEO TODD VASOS’ FY 2019 TOTAL COMPENSATION WAS $12.0 MILLION VERSUS $10.6 MILLION IN FY 2018 - SEC FILING
column7: * DOLLAR GENERAL CORP SAYS FOR 2019, CEO PAY RATIO IS 824:1 Source text for Eikon: (bit.ly/2vCdgF2) Further company coverage:

column4: BRIEF-Dollar General Says First Hour Of Operations To Be Dedicated To Senior Customers
column5: March 16 (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp:
column6: * DOLLAR GENERAL ANNOUNCES FIRST HOUR OF OPERATIONS TO BE DEDICATED TO SENIOR CUSTOMERS
column7: * PLANS TO DEDICATE FIRST HOUR OF EACH SHOPPING DAY TO SENIOR SHOPPERS BEGINNING TOMORROW, MARCH 17
column8: * PLANS TO AMEND STORE OPERATING HOURS BEGINNING TOMORROW, MARCH 17 Source text for Eikon: Further company coverage:

column4: BRIEF-Dollar General Corporation Reports Q4 Earnings Per Share Of $2.10
column5: March 12 (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp:
column6: * ORATION REPORTS STRONG FOURTH QUARTER 2019 FINANCIAL RESULTS
column7: * Q4 EARNINGS PER SHARE ESTIMATE $2.01 -- REFINITIV IBES DATA
column8: * Q4 SALES $7.2 BILLION VERSUS REFINITIV IBES ESTIMATE OF $7.15 BILLION
column9: * BOARD OF DIRECTORS DECLARES INCREASED QUARTERLY CASH DIVIDEND OF $0.36 PER SHARE
column10: * SEES FISCAL YEAR 2020 SAME-STORE SALES GROWTH OF 2.5% TO 3.0%
column11: * DOLLAR GENERAL - AS OF JANUARY 31, 2020, TOTAL MERCHANDISE INVENTORIES, AT COST, WERE $4.7 BILLION COMPARED TO $4.1 BILLION AS OF FEBRUARY 1, 2019

column14: * DOLLAR GENERAL - SEES FISCAL YEAR 2020 CAPITAL EXPENDITURES IN THE RANGE OF $925 MILLION TO $975 MILLION

column16: * DOLLAR GENERAL - DOES NOT EXPECT SUPPLY CHAIN DISRUPTIONS EXPERIENCED TO DATE DUE TO CORONAVIRUS ARE LIKELY TO HAVE A MATERIAL IMPACT ON 2020 RESULTS

column4: Dollar General beats profit estimates, warns of coronavirus uncertainty
column5: (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp DG.N beat quarterly same-store sales and profit expectations on Thursday, as it pulled in more bargain-hungry shoppers to its stores, but warned of uncertainty around its business due to the coronavirus outbreak.
column6: To compete with Dollar Tree Inc DLTR.O as well as low-priced groceries at Walmart Inc WMT.N and Amazon.com Inc AMZN.O, Dollar General has added more higher-margin non-consumable products such as home decorations and party supplies to its shelves to attract more customers.
column7: Same-store sales rose 3.2% in the fourth quarter ended Jan. 31, above analysts’ average estimate of a 2.8% increase, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column8: The company forecast fiscal 2020 same-store sales growth of 2.5% to 3%, compared to analysts’ expectations of 3.1%.
column9: Dollar General said it does not expect recent supply chain disruptions from the coronavirus outbreak to have a material impact on its fiscal 2020 earnings, but warned there was “no guarantee” the rapidly spreading virus would not have a more significant impact on its business.
column10: Net income rose to $535.44 million, or $2.10 per share, in the fourth quarter from $483.24 million, or $1.84 per share, a year earlier. Analysts on average had estimated earnings of $2.01 per share.
column11: Net sales rose to $7.16 billion from $6.65 billion, marginally beating estimates of $7.15 billion.
column12: The company’s share fell 2% before the bell amid plunging broader markets.

column4: Dollar General beats quarterly same-store sales estimates
column5: March 12 (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp beat quarterly same-store sales expectations on Thursday, as it pulled in more bargain-hungry shoppers to its stores.
column6: Same-store sales rose 3.2% in the fourth quarter ended Jan. 31, above analysts’ average estimate of a 2.8% increase, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column7: Net sales rose to $7.16 billion from $6.65 billion, marginally beating estimates of $7.15 billion. (Reporting by Uday Sampath in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

column4: Dollar General to sell CBD cosmetics in select Tennessee and Kentucky stores
column5: (Reuters) - Discount store chain Dollar General Corp DG.N said on Tuesday it would sell cannabidiol (CBD) cosmetic products in more than 1,000 stores in Tennessee and Kentucky, as demand for the products grows.
column6: CBD is a non-psychoactive chemical found in cannabis plants that is known to ease anxiety and other ills without causing a high, and is becoming popular with millennials.
column7: The demand has led several companies, including French luxury goods maker LVMH's LVMH.PA Sephora beauty chain, ULTA Beauty Inc ULTA.O and American Eagle Outfitters Inc AEO.N, to sell CBD-infused creams and lotions.
column8: Dollar General’s CBD assortment is limited to topical cosmetic products, including bath bombs, bath salts and face masks, and it has no plans to provide ingestible or edible CBD merchandise, the company said.
column9: “Our decision to offer CBD products is based on customer interests or demands,” Dollar General Chief Merchandising Officer Jason Reiser said.
column10: The company is planning to expand the availability of its products to seven more U.S. states by spring 2020.

column4: Dollar General to sell CBD cosmetic products in select U.S. stores
column5: Dec 10 (Reuters) - Discount retailer Dollar General Corp said on Tuesday it will sell about 20 cannabidiol (CBD) products, including creams and ointments, in over a thousand stores in Tennessee and Kentucky.
column6: The dollar store said it is also planning to expand availability of the products to seven more U.S. states by spring 2020. (Reporting by Nivedita Balu in Bengaluru; Editing by Vinay Dwivedi)

column4: Dollar General lifts profit forecast, tops third-quarter expectations on sales
column5: (Reuters) - Discount store operator Dollar General Corp DG.N raised its full-year profit forecast on Thursday after reporting its best quarterly same-store sales rise in nearly five years, benefiting from a wider selection of products and revamped stores.
column6: Shares of the company rose about 5% in premarket trading as the retailer raised its adjusted profit for fiscal 2019 to the range of $6.55 to $6.65 per share from $6.45 to $6.60.
column7: The retailer has been aggressively opening hundreds of new stores, creating private label and adding food, health and beauty products to its existing outlets as it tries to better compete with other retailers and grocers.
column8: The efforts boosted same-store sales growth to 4.6% in the third quarter ended Nov. 1, above the average analyst estimate of 3.34% increase, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column9: The company now expects full-year same-store sales to grow in the mid-to-high 3% range compared with the prior low-to-mid 3% range.
column10: The upbeat forecast comes in contrast to rival Dollar Tree Inc DLTR.O, which cut its full-year profit forecast last month, as the discount retailer fell short in its efforts to counter the impact of latest U.S. tariffs on Chinese imports.
column11: Dollar General’s net sales rose 8.9% to $6.99 billion in the quarter, above the estimate of $6.92 billion.
column12: Net income rose to $365.6 million, or $1.42 per share, from $334.1 million, or $1.26 per share, a year earlier.
column13: Analysts on average had expected a profit of $1.38 per share.

column4: Dollar General pays $6 mln to settle EEOC claims of race bias in background checks
column5: Dollar General will pay $6 million and change the way it conducts criminal background checks of job applicants to settle a U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission lawsuit claiming the discount retailer discriminated against black workers with criminal histories.
column6: U.S. District Judge Andrea Wood in Chicago on Monday approved the settlement of the 2013 EEOC lawsuit. In addition to the payout, the company agreed to hire a criminologist to develop a new background check process that accounts for job applicants’ actual risk of recidivism.
column7: To read the full story on WestlawNext Practitioner Insights, click here: bit.ly/32ZpD8s

column4: New products, remodeled stores push U.S. dollar chains to boost profit forecast
column5: (Reuters) - The top two U.S. discount store chains raised their full-year profit forecast on Thursday as a push on adding a range of new products - from fresh food to self-owned brands - starts to pay off, cushioning a blow from increased tariffs on Chinese imports.
column6: U.S. President Donald Trump’s additional tariffs on about $550 billion of Chinese imports announced last week is expected to hurt companies that rely on China for sourcing their products.
column7: The two dollar stores, which source a large chunk of their merchandise from China, are already looking at other sources as the trade war shows no sign of relenting.
column8: Dollar General said on Thursday it would be able to mitigate the impact of these tariffs, while its rival said it was working with suppliers to offset increased costs.
column9: Dollar Tree also said it was able to tide over the previous round of tariffs through price concessions, canceled orders and a better assortment of products.
column10: Dollar General forecast annual earnings of $6.36 per share to $6.51 per share, including the anticipated impact of increased tariffs. It had previously forecast $6.30 to $6.50.
column11: Family Dollar-owner Dollar Tree predicted full-year profit between $4.90 per share and $5.11 per share, but said the forecast excluded the recent tariff increases. Its previous range was $4.77 to $5.07.
column12: The company also reported better-than-expected quarterly same-store sales as its struggling Family Dollar chain posted its best growth since being acquired in 2015.
column13: “We’re getting our core customer back into the store in Family Dollar and they’re liking what they’re seeing,” Dollar Tree Chief Financial Officer Kevin Wampler told analysts.
column14: Hit by competition from big-box retailers like Walmart WMT.N and increased online shopping, the companies have been adding new products on shelves, self-checkout options and frozen food sections to improve shopping experience for customers.
column16: Sales at Dollar General store open for more than an year rose 4% in the reported quarter, well above analysts’ average estimate of a 2.43% increase, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column17: In the past few years, Dollar General has outperformed Dollar Tree as it has been able to stock shelves faster with fresh produce and frozen food at different price points, a key factor for low-income and budget shoppers.
column18: “It’s hard to poke any holes in this report. It was very solid for Dollar General,” Edward Jones analyst Brian Yarbrough said.
column19: Shares of Dollar General Corp DG.N surged 11% to hit a record of $155.98, while those of Dollar Tree Inc DLTR.O rose as much as 4.7%.

column4: Dollar General same-store sales growth beats estimates
column5: Aug 29 (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp beat analysts’ estimates for quarterly same-store sales on Thursday, as more shoppers spent on everyday essentials and seasonal products.
column6: Same-store sales rose 4% in the second quarter ended Aug. 2, well above analysts’ average estimate of a 2.43% increase, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column7: Net income rose to $426.6 million, or $1.65 per share, from $407.2 million, or $1.52 per share, a year earlier. (Reporting by Nivedita Balu in Bengaluru Editing by Saumyadeb Chakrabarty)

column4: IN BRIEF: Dollar General, Dollar Tree settle N.Y. probe into expired products
column5: Discount retail chain operators Dollar General and Dollar Tree will pay a combined $1.2 million to resolve allegations that they sold expired products including over-the-counter drugs, New York’s attorney general said on Monday.
column6: New York Attorney General Letitia James said the settlements resolved an undercover investigation that also found that Dollar General sold obsolete motor oil and that Dollar Tree violated the state’s bottle deposit law.
column7: To read the full story on WestlawNext Practitioner Insights, click here: bit.ly/2U4jQf4

column4: Wall St. steadies after sell-off, but gains muted
column5: NEW YORK (Reuters) - U.S. stocks showed signs of stabilizing on Thursday, but gains were kept in check by conflicting comments on trade talks from President Donald Trump and Beijing that reinforced concerns about a potentially lengthy battle harming global growth.
column6: Trump said talks with China were going well but those comments were countered by a senior Chinese diplomat who said provoking trade disputes is “naked economic terrorism.”
column7: The lack of clarity around the trade battle has rattled investors of late, after the S&P 500 had risen more than 17% through the first four months of the year on optimism a trade deal between the two countries could be reached.
column8: That optimism has faded, however, as the escalating dispute between the two countries has weighed heavily on Wall Street in May, with each of the three main indexes declining at least 5% for the month. Thursday’s gains marked the first advance for major U.S. indexes this week.
column9: “After multiple days of down, down, down the market usually takes a collective breath for some stability and a re-evaluation of risk,” said Ben Phillips, chief investment officer at Eventshares in Newport Beach, California.
column10: “The market is coming to the realization that we are not getting really clean or clear information and it is going to be a lot of noise and just prepare for that.”
column11: A government report on Thursday showed U.S. inflation was much weaker than initially thought in the first quarter on a sharp slowdown in domestic demand, while growth was also slightly lower than estimated in April.
column12: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 43.47 points, or 0.17%, to 25,169.88, the S&P 500 gained 5.85 points, or 0.21%, to 2,788.87 and the Nasdaq Composite added 20.41 points, or 0.27%, to 7,567.72.
column13: Trade jitters helped sustain demand for safe haven debt, as U.S. Treasury yields held near 20-month lows. The yield curve between three-month bills and 10-year notes remained inverted, the inversion the widest in nearly 12 years.
column14: That, in turn, weighed on interest-rate sensitive bank stocks, which dropped 1.2% and were on track for a third straight day of declines, while the broader financial sector declined 0.5%.
column15: The energy sector fell 1.2%, as oil prices settled down nearly 4% in part due to a smaller-than-expected decline in U.S. crude inventories. The sector has fallen more than 10% this month.
column16: Among stocks, Dollar General Corp jumped 7.2% after the discount retailer’s same-store sales and profit topped expectations.
column17: PVH Corp plunged 14.9% as the worst performer on the S&P 500, after the Calvin Klein owner cut its annual profit forecast as it grapples with tariffs and slowing retail growth.
column18: Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones on the NYSE by a 1.11-to-1 ratio; on the Nasdaq, a 1.38-to-1 ratio favored decliners.
column19: The S&P 500 had one new 52-week high and 25 new lows; the Nasdaq Composite 25 new highs and 119 new lows.
column20: About 6.25 billion shares changed hands in U.S. exchanges, compared with the 6.99 billion daily average over the last 20 sessions.

column4: U.S. dollar stores warn of tariff hit after reporting upbeat sales
column5: (Reuters) - Two of America’s largest dollar store chains warned on Thursday that rising tariffs due to escalating trade tensions between Washington and Beijing would hit U.S. shoppers, after reporting strong quarterly sales that sent their shares up about 6%.
column6: Executives from both Dollar Tree and Dollar General fielded questions related to tariffs from analysts on their post-earnings call and said increasing the levies would impact their businesses and consumers.
column7: Several retailers including Walmart Inc, Best Buy, Macy’s and Ralph Lauren have also said that rising tariffs could impact their results this year.
column8: While Dollar General said it expects increased tariffs to lead to higher prices even though it was working with vendors to mitigate the impact, Dollar Tree did not elaborate on the impact of additional levies on its consumers and business.
column9: “Even with these efforts, we believe our shoppers will be facing higher prices as 2019 progress,” Dollar General Chief Financial Officer John Garratt said on the call.
column10: Washington dramatically escalated its trade war with Beijing this month by hiking levies on $200 billion of Chinese goods from 10% to 25% and U.S. President Donald Trump also threatened new tariffs on remaining $300 billion worth U.S. imports from China.
column11: Both companies included the impact of the current tariffs in their full-year forecast.
column12: Dollar General reported better-than-expected results and stuck to its full-year forecast to account for already announced tariffs.
column13: Dollar Tree on the other hand cut its full-year earnings forecast to between $4.77 and $5.07 per share to include a 10- cent hit from store closures and a 5-cent impact from import freight costs.
column14: It had earlier forecast full-year earnings in the range of $4.85 to $5.25 per share.
column15: The companies, however, reported better-than-expected quarterly same-store sales growth as they drew in more customers, benefiting from remodeling stores and stocking more private label products.
column16: Dollar General said it would open 975 stores in 2019 and remodel 1,000 outlets with upgrades, including self-checkout lanes for shoppers who can just scan products and pay through the store app on their phones.
column17: Dollar Tree results also got a boost from a turnaround at its struggling Family Dollar brand. Same-store sales for the brand rose 1.9% in the first quarter, the best growth in two years, beating analysts estimates of a 1.1% rise, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column18: The company is in the process of revamping 1,000 Family Dollar stores with improved merchandise, including $1 items and adding coolers and alcohol to some of its stores.
column19: “The steps being taken to improve performance at Family Dollar appear to be working,” managing director of GlobalData Retail Neil Saunders said.

column4: Dollar General's strong same-store sales, profit beat lift shares
column5: (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp beat analysts’ estimates for quarterly same-store sales and profit on Thursday, as customers spent more on groceries, seasonal products and home goods at the discount retailer’s stores, sending its shares up 6%.
column6: The company has been lining store shelves with more private labels for health and beauty products among others, while also selling groceries and other items at lower prices in a bid to boost sales.
column7: The retailer has been also revamping its stores. In 2019, it would open 975 stores and remodel 1,000 outlets with upgrades, including self-checkout lanes for shoppers who can just scan products and pay through the store app on their phones, the company said.
column8: “We have a wide variety of initiatives and projects that we believe can help extend our growth trajectory over both the near and longer term,” Chief Executive Officer Todd Vasos said in a statement.
column9: The company kept its full-year forecast unchanged, accounting for any anticipated impact of increased tariff rates on certain products imported from China. The outlook, however, did not factor in any additional increases in levies.
column10: The company reported a 3.8% rise in same-store sales, beating the average analyst estimate of a 2.88% increase, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column11: Net income rose to $385 million, or $1.48 per share, in the first quarter ended May 3, from $364.9 million, or $1.36 per share, a year earlier.
column12: Analysts were expecting the company to earn $1.39 per share.
column13: Net sales rose to $6.62 billion from $6.11 billion, also beating expectations of $6.57 billion.

column4: Dollar General sees higher prices for U.S. shoppers on rising tariffs
column5: (Reuters) - Dollar General Chief Financial Officer John Garratt said on Thursday that customers of the discount retailers will face higher prices due to rising tariffs.
column6: Garratt on a post-earnings call said the company has been implementing different strategies to mitigate the impact of tariffs, including negotiations with vendors.
column7: “But even with these efforts, we believe our shoppers will be facing higher prices as 2019 progress,” he said.
column8: Washington dramatically escalated its trade war with Beijing this month by hiking levies on $200 billion of Chinese goods from 10% to 25% and U.S. President Donald Trump also threatened new tariffs on remaining $300 billion worth U.S. imports from China.

column4: Dollar General sees higher prices for U.S. shoppers on rising tariffs
column5: May 30 (Reuters) - Dollar General Chief Financial Officer John Garratt said on Thursday that customers of the discount retailers will face higher prices due to rising tariffs.
column6: Garratt on a post-earnings call said the company has been implementing different strategies to mitigate the impact of tariffs, including negotiations with vendors.
column7: “But even with these efforts, we believe our shoppers will be facing higher prices as 2019 progress,” he said.
column8: Washington dramatically escalated its trade war with Beijing this month by hiking levies on $200 billion of Chinese goods from 10% to 25% and U.S. President Donald Trump also threatened new tariffs on remaining $300 billion worth U.S. imports from China. (Reporting by Aishwarya Venugopal in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

column4: Dollar General beats quarterly same-store sales estimates
column5: May 30 (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp beat analysts’ estimates for quarterly same-store sales on Thursday, as customers spent more on groceries, seasonal products and home goods at the discount retailer’s stores.
column6: The company reported a 3.8% rise in same-store sales, beating the average analyst estimate of a 2.88% increase, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column7: Net income rose to $385 million, or $1.48 per share, in the first quarter ended May 3, from $364.9 million, or $1.36 per share, a year earlier. (Reporting by Aishwarya Venugopal in Bengaluru; Editing by Shinjini Ganguli)

column4: Higher store investments to hit Dollar General profit, shares fall 10 pct
column5: (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp will plow back a part of its 2019 profit to revamp its supply chain and add self-checkout lanes at its stores as it competes with online grocers and U.S. chains Walmart Inc and Kroger Co.
column6: Shares of the discount retailer fell nearly 10 percent on Thursday after it projected full-year profit below analysts’ expectations and said it would spend $50 million for the initiatives.
column7: The company, which operates more than 15,000 stores in the United States, said it would open 975 new stores and remodel 1,000 old ones. The upgrades would include introducing self-checkout lanes and tweaking its shelf stocking process to make it faster.
column8: Dollar General also said by the end of fiscal 2019 it aims to become its own distributor of fresh and frozen foods to as many as 5,000 stores in a bid to rein in costs and offer more private label brands.
column9: “We have some distribution voids quite frankly, across the country.... By taking it in-house, we believe it will simplify our network and be able to execute that much better,” Chief Executive Officer Todd Vasos said in an earnings call.
column10: While these steps would pressure earnings this year, Dollar General said it would lead to cost savings as early as 2020.
column11: To pull in more customers, Dollar General will start its own click-and-collect service later this year and also launch its private label baby product and cosmetics brands.
column12: Dollar General said it expects to earn $6.30 to $6.50 per share in fiscal 2019, below the average analyst estimate of $6.65, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column13: Excluding items, the company earned $1.84 per share in the fourth quarter ended Feb. 1 but missed the average analyst estimate of $1.88, blaming on higher transportation cost and lower sales of high-margin products.
column14: However, the company’s same-store sales rose 4 percent and beat the 2.6 percent increase analysts had estimated, as its customers, who benefited from an earlier-than-usual distribution of food stamps, spent more on groceries.
column15: Net sales rose 8.5 percent to $6.65 billion and beat analysts’ expectations of $6.61 billion.
column16: Rival Dollar Tree Inc’s shares were down 1.31 percent. The company last week reported better-than-expected same-store sales, but wrote down the value of its Family Dollar chain by $2.7 billion after years of stagnating sales.

column4: Dollar General beats quarterly same-store sales estimates, raises dividend
column5: March 14 (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp reported better-than-expected same-store sales on Thursday, as its customers spent more on groceries at the discount retailer’s stores, benefiting from an earlier-than-usual issue of food stamps.
column6: Same-store sales rose 4 percent in the fourth-quarter ended Feb. 1, beating the 2.6 percent increase analysts had estimated, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column7: Net sales rose to $6.65 billion from $6.13 billion.
column8: The company also raised its quarterly dividend by 10 percent and increased its share buyback program by $1 billion.

column4: Dollar General cuts forecast on hurricane costs, warns of tariff hit
column5: (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp DG.N cut its full-year profit and sales forecasts on Tuesday and warned that proposed tariffs on Chinese imports could begin to have a greater impact on its business and customers, sending its shares down as much as 8.6 percent.
column6: The company topped profit estimates for the third quarter when excluding a 5-cent per share impact from hurricanes Florence and Michael, but said the fallout would reduce its holiday-quarter profit by 4 cents.
column7: Dollar General has a large number of stores in the eastern and southern coastal areas damaged by the storms, but did not say how many stores were affected.
column8: One of America’s biggest discount chains, the company warned that if Washington followed through on threats to raise tariffs to 25 percent, it was likely to hurt more.
column9: The company directly imports about 5 percent to 6 percent of its merchandise, a substantial amount of which still comes from China, and said that many vendors also have supply deals in the country, making the entire supply chain vulnerable to higher tariffs.
column10: Dollar General said it was working with vendors to reduce costs and considering other options to ease the blow from tariffs, including shifting manufacturing to other countries or stocking substitute products that are not subject to tariffs.
column11: Few U.S. retailers have made much of the trade war so far, playing down the impact on their bottom lines, but with the U.S. economy showing signs of slowing, it would add to a growing list of headaches.
column12: Like several other retailers, Dollar General also flagged higher freight costs, as a shortage of truck drivers, new driver regulations and higher fuel prices made moving freight much costlier.
column13: The company cut its full-year profit forecast to $5.85 to $6.05 per share from the prior forecast of $5.95 to $6.15 per share, falling well below analysts’ average estimate of $6.11, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column14: Investors were also worried about the company’s flat store traffic in the third quarter and pressures on its gross margins, which fell 39 basis points to 29.5 percent, primarily due to the direct and indirect impact of tariffs and higher freight costs.
column15: Still, the company stuck to its aggressive investment plans to remodel and open new stores.
column16: “While we expect gross margin pressure to continue through FY20, we expect 2019 initiatives to penetrate urban areas, expand key non-consumables and strengthen health and beauty offerings to drive future momentum,” CFRA analyst Camilla Yanushevsky wrote in a note.
column17: The disappointing forecast and gross margin pressure overshadowed better-than-expected quarterly same-store sales, which rose 2.8 percent for the quarter ended Nov. 2, topping the 2.43 percent increase forecast by analysts.
column18: Shares of the company, which have risen 20 percent this year, fell 8.5 percent to $102.22 in afternoon trading.
column19: Net income rose to $334.14 million, or $1.26 per share, from $252.53 million, or 93 cents per share, a year earlier.
column20: Net sales rose 8.7 percent to $6.42 billion, beating analysts’ estimate of $6.38 billion.

column4: Dollar General beats quarterly same-store sales estimates
column5: Dec 4 (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp reported better-than-expected same-store sales in its third quarter, bolstered by strong sales of fast moving consumable goods as well as its seasonal and home offerings.
column6: Same-store sales at the retail chain rose 2.8 percent for the quarter ended Nov 2, topping the 2.43 percent increase forecast by analysts, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column7: Net income rose to $334.14 million, or $1.26 per share, from $252.53 million, or 93 cents per share, a year earlier. (Reporting by Soundarya J and Ishita Chigilli Palli in Bengaluru; editing by Patrick Graham)

column4: Dollar Tree stock is a bargain, down 18 percent this year: Barron's
column5: NEW YORK (Reuters) - Shares of Dollar Tree Inc DLTR.O are as big a bargain as the $1 goods it sells in its stores, with shares off 18 percent this year and trading at a discount to its biggest competitor Dollar General Corp DG.N and there is a possible activist investor in the wings, according to Barron's.
column6: The U.S. financial newspaper said that Dollar Tree is trading at near a five-year low but could bounce back. The company has been punished for its purchase of rival Family Dollar, but has begun renovating and rebranding the struggling Family Dollar stores, it said.
column7: Barron’s said that analysts have been speculating on an activist investor may be interested. Carl Icahn and Nelson Peltz were Family Dollar shareholders who had encouraged a sale before the Dollar Tree acquisition, the newspaper reported.
column8: The New York Post reported in October that Icahn was accumulating shares in the company.

column4: Dollar General quarterly same-store sales top estimates
column5: Aug 30 (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp’s quarterly same-store sales topped analysts’ estimates on Thursday as more customers shopped for apparel and groceries at the discount store chain.
column6: Same-store sales rose 3.7 percent in the three months ended Aug. 3, above the 2.83 percent increase estimated by analysts on average, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column7: The company’s net income rose to $407.2 million, or $1.52 per share, from $294.8 million, or $1.08 per share, a year earlier.
column8: Dollar General’s net sales rose to $6.44 billion from $5.83 billion. (Reporting by Aishwarya Venugopal in Bengaluru Editing by Saumyadeb Chakrabarty)

column4: 8th Circuit revives vet's USERRA claims against Dollar General
column5: A U.S. appeals court on Friday said that members of the military who apply for new jobs with their former employers upon returning from deployment are protected by the federal law requiring companies to rehire veterans.
column6: A unanimous three-judge panel of the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals revived a lawsuit against Dollar General parent Dolgencorp LLC by Samuel Scudder, a National Guardsman who said the company refused to hire him to manage a different Arkansas store than the one where he worked before he was deployed to Afghanistan.
column7: To read the full story on Westlaw Practitioner Insights, click here: bit.ly/2L7ZM5G

column4: U.S. hedge funds bet on retail, tech in second-quarter as economy sizzled
column5: (Reuters) - Prominent hedge fund managers appeared to make big second-quarter bets that the U.S. economy would continue to expand despite increasing concerns about a broadening trade dispute between the United States and China, regulatory filings showed Tuesday.
column6: Third Point added new positions in payment companies PayPal Holdings Inc PYPL.O and Visa Inc V.N, both of which are up more than 19 percent year to date. Greenlight Capital, run by billionaire investor David Einhorn, added new positions in low-to-middle income retailers including Dollar Tree Inc DLTR.O, Dollar General Corp DG.N, Gap Inc GPS.N, and TJX Companies Inc TJX.N, the parent company of discount retailers TJ Maxx and HomeGoods.
column7: Activist fund Jana Partners added shares of broad-based exchange-traded funds that track the S&P 500 and the Russell 2000 indexes and took new positions in Wells Fargo & Co WFC.N and food delivery company GrubHub Inc GRUB.N.
column8: The flurry of new positions in cyclical companies came during a quarter in which U.S. gross domestic product increased at an annual rate of 4.1 percent, nearly double the 2.2 percent rate of the first quarter of the year, according to Commerce Department estimates.
column9: A rally in cyclical companies would help boost hedge fund industry returns at a time when many fund firms are under pressure from investors to lower their fees or improve their performance. Hedge funds, on average, are up 1.5 percent since the start of January, according to research firm Hedge Fund Research, well behind the 6.2 percent gain in the benchmark S&P 500 index over the same time.
column10: “Everyone is comparing everything to the S&P 500 and that’s a very difficult hurdle for the last few years,” said Sol Waksman, president of research firm BarclayHedge.
column11: Quarterly disclosures of hedge fund managers’ stock holdings, in what are known as 13F filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, are one of the few public ways of learning what the managers are selling and buying. But relying on the filings to develop an investment strategy comes with some risk because the disclosures come 45 days after the end of each quarter and may not reflect current positions. Still, the filings offer a glimpse into what hedge fund managers saw as opportunities to make money on the long side.
column12: The filings do not disclose short positions, or bets that a stock will fall in price. As a result, the public filings do not always present a complete picture of a management firm’s stock holdings.
column13: Large hedge fund managers cut their positions in some of the so-called FAANG stocks - the moniker given to Facebook Inc FB.O, Apple Inc AAPL.O, Amazon.com Inc AMZN.O, Netflix Inc NFLX.O, and Google-parent Alphabet Inc GOOGL.O - that led the market higher last year.
column14: Third Point sold all of its stake in Alphabet and divested 1 million shares of Facebook, reducing its position in the company by 25 percent. At the same time, it increased its stake in Microsoft Corp MSFT.O by nearly 310 percent, buying 1.7 million shares.
column15: Omega Advisors, meanwhile, sold all of its position in Netflix and added new holdings in biotechnology companies including Madrigal Pharmaceuticals Inc MDGL.O and Deciphera Pharmaceuticals Inc DCPH.O.
column16: A number of prominent fund managers sharply cut their stake in Apple only weeks before it became the first publicly traded U.S. company to be worth more than $1 trillion.
column17: Einhorn’s Greenlight Capital slashed its stake by 77 percent, while Philippe Laffont’s Coatue Management got rid of 95 percent. Advisory firm Diamond Hill Capital Management cut its stake by 27 percent. Other big holders, including Sanders Capital and Adage Capital Partners, trimmed only small amounts in the second quarter.

column4: Dollar Tree, Dollar General same-store sales disappoint, shares fall
column5: (Reuters) - Two of America’s biggest dollar store chains missed Wall Street estimates for same-store sales as higher household income encouraged customers to shop more at big box retailers and an unusually cold spring weather crimped demand for seasonal products.
column6: Dollar Tree's DLTR.O shares fell 11.5 percent to $85.29 on Thursday, also pressured by a surprise drop in comparable sales at its struggling Family Dollar unit. Dollar General DG.N fell 8 percent to $88.72.
column7: Colder-than-usual weather in March and April in many parts of the country hit traffic at several U.S. retailers, leaving popular spring clothing items and garden equipment and supplies unsold.
column8: Dollar Tree bought Family Dollar in 2015 to better compete against larger chains such as Walmart Inc WMT.N and Kroger Co KR.N and attract more lower-income customers.
column9: While the deal made the company the top U.S. dollar store chain by stores, it has struggled to turn around Family Dollar amid intensifying competition in the grocery industry with the entry of German discounters Aldi and Lidl.
column10: Adding to the company’s woes, tax refunds, a booming stock market and one-time bonuses have put more money into wallets this year, spurring customers to move to big box chains that offer more choices and have slashed prices, said Neil Saunders, managing director of consultancy GlobalData Retail.
column11: This hit same-store sales at the 8,000 odd Family Dollar stores, which fell 1.1 percent, compared with analysts’ expectation of a 1.45 percent rise, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S. Closer rival Dollar General also faced similar pressure, resulting in a lower-than-expected same-store sales growth of 2.1 percent in the first quarter.
column12: “The canary in the coal mine out of the print is the negative comparable sales out of Family Dollar,” said Gordon Haskett analyst Chuck Grom. “While DG’s softer comparable sales help explain some of the softness ... but such results (from Family Dollar) are becoming more concerning to us.”
column13: Dollar Tree and Dollar General also posted on Thursday earnings per share for the first quarter that missed estimates, hurt in part by higher freight costs.
column14: Both retailers warned freight costs would continue to weigh on full-year profits, with Dollar Tree cutting its forecast. Dollar General, on the other hand, maintained its full-profit forecast.
column15: “(Freight) costs are trending higher than our original guidance,” Dollar Tree Chief Financial Officer Kevin Wampler said.
column16: Dollar Tree cut its annual profit forecast to between $4.80 and $5.10 per share, while Dollar General expects earnings of $5.95-$6.15 per share.
column17: Analysts on average had expected full-year earnings of $5.66 and $6.08 for Dollar Tree and Dollar General, respectively.
column18: Excluding items, Dollar General earned $1.36 per share, falling short of analysts’ expectation of $1.40. Dollar Tree earned $1.19 per share, missing the estimate of $1.23.

column4: Dollar General same-store sales miss estimates
column5: May 31 (Reuters) - Dollar General Corp on Thursday reported first-quarter same-store sales below analysts’ forecasts, as the discount store chain faced weaker demand for apparel and home products because of cold weather.
column6: Same-store sales rose 2.1 percent in the three months ended May 4, less than the 3.24 percent increase expected by analysts on average, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column7: Dollar General’s net income rose to $364.9 million or $1.36 per share, from $279.5 million or $1.02 per share a year earlier. (Reporting by Aishwarya Venugopal in Bengaluru; Editing by Sai Sachin Ravikumar)
